revised_title: The Divergent Notions of Nature in Reynolds and Hunter's Lectures at the Royal Academy of Arts
tldr: This article discusses the contrasting views of Sir Joshua Reynolds and Dr William Hunter on the imitation of nature in their lectures at the Royal Academy of Arts. Reynolds believed in the ideal imitation of nature, while Hunter emphasized direct naturalism and observational science. Their divergent perspectives resulted from their distinct backgrounds and intellectual tools, shaping the art and anatomy disciplines in the 18th century.
